div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,574] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINE, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m., a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE SINAITIC DELIMITATION.
div.p: Shortly before we went to press yesterday afternoon we received a telephonic message from our Cairo correspondent to say that the treaty concerning the delimitation of the Sinaitic eastern boundary had been signed. By this successful termination of a dispute, which at one point necessitated a forcible naval demonstration by the British navy, Egypt, thanks to British support and to the justice of her case—emerges with success from a diplomatic combat which might have had serious consequences, and the satisfaction of the authorities can only be heightened by the difficulty with which this happy end has been attained.

In itself the Sinai is of no importance—a waterless and rugged region, frequented only by antiquarians and Bedouins; it offered no prize to the contending parties in the recent negotiations. But as the gate of Egypt possessed enormous strategical importance That arid triangle of sand and rocks with its base on the Mediterranean and its apex on the Red Sea has been traversed by most of the conquerors of Egypt. The Hyksos, the army of "barbarians" that marched from Western Asia against the third Rameses passed through it. The Egyptian conquerors of Syria followed the famous road from Pelusium to Gaza, and in later days, when the Assyrian and Babylonian kings avenged themselves on the Pharaohs, Sargon won a victory at Rafah—where Ptolemies and Selucids, Mamelukes and Mongols were to fight, and Turks and Egyptians to wrangle—and Esarhaddon and Assurbanipal, Nebuchadnezzer, and last of all the Persian conquerors under Cambyses invaded unhappy Egypt by this route. The pageant of Arab conquerors, Mameluke kings, crusading raiders, and great captains who marched over its sands is fitly closed by the names of Ibrahim Pasha and Napoleon Bonaparte.

Need it then surprise even the most hardened advocate of "peace at any price" that the discovery that the Hedjaz railway had enabled the Turks to bring their troops from the Syrian garrison towns to within striking distance of the frontier by a new route, hitherto unknown to the annals of military history, caused a certain uneasiness to the British and Egyptian Governments ; that the strange demand of Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha aggravated this uneasiness and that the Moslem population of Egypt—divided between Khalif and Khedive—showed for almost the first time a keen, if credulous, interest in a question of external politics and a disquiet that Lord Cromer has characterised as natural enough. The British Government rose to the occasion. It wisely increased the garrison of Egypt while strengthening the hand of the Egyptian Foreign Office by vigorous diplomatic support, and thanks to its intervention an amicable basis of agreement was at last discovered through the application of an ultimatum—not the first which the Ottoman Empire has received from a foreign power, nor, we daresay, the last.

The diplomatic struggle has been fruitful in results. The British colony in Egypt has learnt who are the foes and who the friends of the British Occupation. They have realised that there are cases in which it is naïveté, and childish naïveté, to expect that a doubtful gratitude for benefits conferred will outweigh religious and political prejudice. They have learned that the great majority of the Europeans resident in Egypt, all the wiser and more cautious among the Moslems, and, with trifling exceptions, the Syrians and the Copts are with them : they have also learned the strength and fathomed the motives of the leaders of the opposition which is directed against not only alone British but against all European influence and control, and they have been able to guess the origin of the agitation steadily and often skilfully fomented by highly placed intriguers both within Egypt and without. Moreover they know now that Egypt is not invulnerable and though the successful delimitation of the frontier has removed all immediate danger they realise the truth of the proverb "Forewarned is forearmed." It is our earnest hope that the home Government will be as prompt as its distinguished representative in Egypt in grasping the full significance of the Tabah incident and its sequel.

H.H. the Khedive and Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha, who have just returned, will no doubt be delighted to find that a possible cause of dispute between Egypt and the Suzerain Power has been removed. The frontier line will appear on future atlases as a straight line drawn from Rafah to a point a little to the N.W. of the head of the Gulf of Akaba and will then terminate with a semicircular sweep half way up the Nakhl el Akaba and back to the sea at Ras Tabah. From Rafah it passes through the country of the Sawarka Bedouin, crosses the hill of Ras el Ain and leaving Birein wells on the Turkish side passes six miles east of the wells and stream of Ain Kadeis (Kadesh Barnea) and 14 miles east of Kuseima, past Thamilet Sueilma to Ras Radadi, a spur jutting from the edge of the Sinaitic plateau and close to the Nakhl el Akaba, the upper portion of which with the post of Mufrak remains in Egyptian hands. Then the frontier sweeps down into the plain to the Tabah cape. The concession of a small area near Akaba should relieve the Ottoman Government of the anxiety which it professed to cherish as to Egyptian and British designs on Akaba and indirectly on the Hedjaz railway.

Our Nationalists may claim it as a triumph for the Khalif: they may do so if it pleases them, for no one will be a penny the worse, and we cannot help thinking that in a few years' time relations between Great Britain and the Turkish Empire will be enormously improved, and that the evidence furnished by the agreement that England neither has any designs in Petræa nor intends to use Egypt as a catspaw should calm the fears of the more reasonable among Osmanli Anglophobes. We offer our hearty congratulations to the Egyptian Government and to Lord Cromer, Mr. M. de C. Findlay, and the other members of the British Agency, whose diplomatic support and energetic but patient conduct of delicate negotiations has met with such success. High praise is also due to Ibrahim Pasha Fathi and to Major R. Owen and their staff for the patience with which they surveyed, argued, and negotiated. The two commissioners are not yet back from Rafah after an absence of close on eighteen weeks in a region which has not improved since the Israelites—much against the grain—wandered over its wastes. They have established excellent relations with the Turkish frontier officers, and the final success of their labours will compensate them for an arduous task admirably carried out.

div.head: The Cattle Plague.
div.p: The district of Bibeh is now included among those pronounced infected by cattle plague.

div.head: Drafts for Egypt
div.p: The hired transport Sicilia left England on the 29th ult., with drafts for Egypt and elsewhere.

div.head: The "Sucreries" Line.
div.p: The Ministry of Finance has opened a credit of L.E. 390,000, for purchasing the "Sucreries" railway.

div.head: Alexandria Swimming Clnb.
div.p: The prizes for the sports championships are on view at Messrs. Davies Bryan and Co.'s establishment.

div.head: The Austrian Agency.
div.p: The members of the Austro-Hungarian Diplomatic Agency have re-transferred their quarters to Cairo.

div.head: Legislative Council.
div.p: The next meeting of the Legislative Council will be held on the 1st December when it will deal with the budget and other matters.

div.head: Army Dental Surgeon.
div.p: Mr. A. E. Shellard, Dental Surgeon to the Army of Occupation, Alexandria, resumes his usual winter hours—viz. 9 a.m. till 1 p.m. and 3 p.m. till 5 p.m.

div.head: Increases of Salary.
div.p: Nineteen officials of the Irrigation Service have received an increase of salary in accordance with the new regulations drawn up by the Commission of which Lord Edward Cecil is president.

div.head: Constanza to Alexandria.
div.p: The Imperatul Trajan, of the Roumanian Steam Navigation Co., passed through the Bosphorus on the 23rd September en route for Constanza, whence she will shortly start on the maiden voyage to Alexandria.

div.head: The Syrian Mutineers.
div.p: The four Syrian convicts who escaped from the Turkish transport Koswa, which, it will beremembered, passed through the canal recently in company with the Assyr, and who were imprisoned at Ismailia when captured, have been set at liberty.

div.head: New Honours List.
div.p: At the end of next month, the moudiriehs and other official departments will submit to the Khedive their list of the ranks of honour and decorations to he conferred upon a number of Omdehs and other officials.

div.head: Hashish Seizure.
div.p: Advices from the Piræus report that a large quantity of hashish was confiscated on board the Hellenic steamer Ourania, of the Pantaleon line. It belonged to a Turk named Mustapha Mehmed, who intended exporting it to Alexandria.

div.head: "Al Moayad."
div.p: Yesterday our Arabic contemporary, "Al Moayad," appeared in its enlarged edition of forty eight colnmns. We congratulate our contemporary on its appearance, which is a signal testimony to the great abilities of Sheikh Aly Youssef. Yesterday's issue contained a highly interesting history of our contemporary, which began its life on December 1, 1889.

div.head: Hotel Beau Rivage.
div.p: The following visitors are staying at the Beau Rivage Hotel, Ramleh : Dr. and Mrs. H. Engel, Mr. EL Tependorf, Miss Tependorf, Mr. N. Rolo, Mr. and Mrs. B. Sanner, Mr. C. div.head: Reuter's Agency.
div.p: A correspondent points ont to ns that in yesterday's issue we announced in a Renter's telegram from Teheran that "Mr." Spring Rice had arrived, whereas, as our correspondent notes, the knightly prefix ought to have been added. We were, however, perfectly well aware that this gentleman has been knighted, but we always reproduce Reuter's telegrams textually, as it would be a somewhat invidious task to edit them. We publish them in accordance with the printed edition of the telegrams sent out to subscribers, and are in no wise responsible for the many an various mistakes made in editing the telegrams. As an example of the strange ignorance of titles displayed by the agent responsible for editing these telegrams we may mention the way in which Prince Arthur of Connaught was styled "Duke of Connaught" in the telegrams regarding the Garter Mission to Japan last winter.

div.head: GHIZEH TRANSFORMED.
div.p: A correspondent writes :—

The march of progress in Cairo is rapidly turning one of the most beautiful cities in the Near East into a wilderness of bricks and mortar. As an instance of the damage that is being done to the charm and repose which characterised many of the outlying parts of the Capital, I may mention the havoc now being perpetrated at Ghizeh. The way that district isbeing out up by new roads is terrible. Trees are being felled and unsightly houses are springing up like mushrooms in the vicinity of the Reformatory. The road which passes the Reformatory is encumbered for a long distance with huge beams and piles of stones for building, leaving a passage so narrow that there will surely be some serious carriage accidents. The feverish rate at which the new buildings, are being run up bodes ill for their stability. It is incredible in what a brief space of time one of the most beautiful parts of Cairo's environs has been changed into an unsightly building site.

div.head:
THE RAILWAY CONFERENCE.
REBUFF TO MR. BELL.

div.p: After angry scenes, at the Conference of the Society of Railway servants held at Cardiff, the resolution was carried requiring the railwaymen's parliamentary candidates to sign the pledge of the Independent Labour Party. This is regarded as a rebuff to Mr. Bell, M.P., who strongly opposed the resolution and as a triumph for Mr. Keir Hardie. (Reuter)
The Scottish miners have asked the Coal Conciliation Board for a 12 1/4 per cent. increase in wages.
20,000 of the Rhondda and Pontypridd miners have given notice that they will cease work on 31st October unless the non-members of the Union join the Federation. (Reuter)

At the trial at Kherson of 97 peasants charged with destroying an estate, it transpired that the Cossacks beat 23 peasants to death. 130 were terribly injured. All of them were innocent men, the real culprits having fled. (Reuter)
While the Ministers of Marine and Finance were motoring to La Granja to see King Alfonso their car overturned. They were pinned underneath and badly bruised.(Reuter)

The "Kolnisohe Zeitung," while asserting the right of Germantrade to extend its field of operations to Persia, denies that Germany has any idea of ousting British or Russian influence. The establishment of a German Bank in Persia has nothing whatever to do with loan operations. (Reuter)
A very satisfactory agreement as to the Sinaibonndary was signed last night by the Turkish and Egyptian CommissionerB.(Reuter)

M. Taft, in his address at the opening of the Havana University, said that the sole objects of the intervention on the part of the United States was to assist the Cubans to resume the progress they had been making. (Reuter)
The reports with regard to the damage to the cotton crop have been confirmed. (Reuter)
The entire armament of the Montagu has been salved. (Reuter)
The Emperor, who is completely restored to health, has returned to Vienna from Schoen- brnnn. ( Havas)
The Consuls of the protecting Powers have installed M. Zaimis in office. (Havas)
The steam trials of the Dreadnooght are officially reported as having been most satisfactory. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE KHEDIVE.
ARRIVAL AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The Khedive paid his farewell visit to the Sultan at noon on Sunday, and lunched at Yildiz Palace. His Highness then drove to the Mahroussa, accompanied by Zeky Pasha, Izzet Bey, Dr. Ramadan Bey and Sagh.Tewfik Effendi. Ferik Husny Pasha bade his Highness goodbye on board in the name of the Sultan. The Mahroussa weighed anchor at 10 p.m. on Sunday, and averaged a speed of sixteen knots an hour. The sea and the climatic conditions left nothing to be desired. On Monday the Mahroussa arrived at Chanak Kuleh where the Turkish fort saluted. She wassighted making Alexandria at 7.40 p.m. last nigh and came to anchor at 9 p.m. His Highness spent the night on board.

The Ministers were received on board by the Khedive and had a long audience with him. His Highness mentioned in the course of conversation that the Sultan was in better health and was able to attend Friday prayers last week.
His Highness disembarked at 5 o'clock this morning, and proceeded to Ras-el-Tin palace.
The Khedivah and her children left the Mahroussa at 7.30 o'clook this morning.
Among the local magnates received in audience by the Khedive last night were the Governor of Alexandria, Gedge Pasha, and Ahmed Shefik Bey.
The Khedive's palace on the Bosphorus at Tchiboukli is nearly finished, and his Highness contemplates spending a part of next summer there with his family.
His Highness looks in the best of health.
Mahmoud Bey Mohamed, of the Khedive's Arabic Bureau, who accompanied his Highness to Constantinople, has remained there, and will return to Alexandria next week.
From Constantinople the Mahroussa was under the command of Bimbashi Ahmed Bakri, son of the harbourmaster of Alexandria.
Among other callers at Bebek palace on the Khedive was the Hellenic Minister at Constantinople, M. Gryparis, who is an intimate acquaintance of his Highness.

div.head: THE COLDSTREAM GUARDS.
div.p: As reported by our special telegram of the 26th ult., the 3rd Battalion Coldstream Regiment, one of those of the Brigade of Foot Guards recently scheduled for disbandment, but since ordered to undertake a tour of duty in Egypt, was inspected to-day week at Wellington Barracks by Major-General the Hon. Sir Frederick W. Stopford, commanding the London district. The battalion, which embarked on Saturday at Southampton, paraded in its full home establishment strength, viz., 709 officers and men, under the command of Lieutenant-Colonel Granville R. F. Smith, and presented an exceptionally fine appearance. All ranks have for the present discarded their tunics and busbies, and paraded in smart- fitting scarlet kerseys and white solar helmets, and otherwise in marching order.

Shortly before the arrival of the inspecting officer General Sir Frederick Stephenson (Constable of the Tower), Colonel of the Cold- Stream Guards, walked on to the parade- ground and was received with a general salute. When Sir Frederick Stopford arrived the troops again presented arms, and the band of the regiment played a march. The Major-General was accompanied by Lieutenant Earl Stanhope, aide-de-camp., Colonel H. G. D. Shute, Assistant Adjutant and Quartermaster- General of the District, and Major J. McC. Steel, Brigade Major. The battalion, which received the inspecting officer in line, was immediately formed into column, and the companies were closely scrutinised in succession. The leading company having been dealt with, it was marched off, and subsequently reappeared wearing khaki uniform of tropical texture.

There was no formal march past, but the inspection, which was watched by large crowds assembled in Birdcage walk, occupied considerably over an hour. In addition to the Lieutenant-Colonel commanding, the field officers of the battalion on parade were Major J. A. G. Richardson-Drummond-Hay (second in command), Major the Earl of Lanesborough, Major Pereira, and Lieutenant J. E. Gibbs, adjutant.

They were subsequently addressed by General Stopford, who said that on Saturday next they would proceed to Egypt, where history would tell them the regiment had added many additional laurels to their wreath. In 1802, in landing in Egypt, they waded ashore, and at the point of the bayonet secured a permanent footing, losing in doing so more officers and men than any other corps. In the 1880's the regiment was again in Egypt for three years, and well sustained the reputation of the Guards. The presence of their veteran colonel should he a great incentive to them all to act up to the traditions of the glorious records set by their predecessors. On their behaviour in front of the Egyptian troops, with the eyes of representatives of all civilized nations upon them, depended perhaps their continuance in the service as a separate regiment. The parade was then dismissed.

div.head:
THE NATIONAL UNIVERSITY.
SUBSCRIPTION LIST OPENED.
div.p: A subscription list has beenopened in the native Press for the establishment of an Egyptian National University by Mustapha Effendi el Ghamrawi, a notable of Beni Souef, who has expressed his willingness to subscribe L.E. 500 provided that the following conditions are fulfilled:
(1) The University must be open to Egyptians of all creeds.
(2) The direction mast be in the hands of reliable persons.
(3) The subscribers must number not less than one thousand, each of whioh must subscribe a minimum of L.E. 100.
(4) The University must be built on a suitable site on the bank of the Nile at Cairo.

A subscription of L.E. 1,000 has been offered by Said Hassan Alid el Kader Djamjoum, and Mohamed Bey Hassib, proprietor of the Arabic 'Review of Reviews," and Mahmoud Bey Zuhdi have each promised to subscribe L E. 1,000.

It has not yet been notified what sum will be subscribed by Mustapha Pasha Kamel, but we are glad to learn that Egypt's "Patriot" has cast aside for the nonce his accustomed modesty and expressed his willingness to lay the foundation stone.

div.head: THE KAMEL BANQUET.
div.p: The discussion as to the policy of giving a banquet in honour of Mustapha Pasha Kamel's return to Egypt still rages in the columns of the native Press. Mahmoud Hassib Bey; Editor of the Arabic "Review of Reviews," writes to "Al Minbar" declaring that no valid reason exists against welcoming the "Patriot" in this manner. He protests against the point of view taken up by another correspondent, who bases his opposition to the banquet on the grounds that the organisers of and participants in this function ran the risk of incurring the displeasure of Lord Cromer. There is no ground for fearing Lord Cromer's resentment, says the Bey, for his Lordship is well aware of the sincerity and moral courage which Kamel has shown in defending the rights of his native land whereby he has gained the sympathy of his countrymen as well as the respect of many wise men in Europe. Such a hero is worthy of being honoured just as he was honoured by the Indians in London. The reception that these gentlemen gave the Pasha there should be an example to the Egyptians of how his Excellenoy ought to he received. As to the fear of raising Lord Cromer's wrath by any such proceeding, he, on the contrary, will appreciate such a manifestation of exalted sentiment. The writer concludes as follows : "If Mustapha Pasha Kamel hates the English, and is detested and menaced by British Officialdom in Egypt, would it not be an act of treachery to desert this man, who for so long has been defending our rights ? Such conduct would be extraordinarily ungrateful. The function merely consists in a banquet at a Cairo hotel and in the presentation of a memento of our recognition of the services he has rendered. Surely such proceedings do not amount to a serious political manifestation?"
"Al Minbar," in an editorial note on the same subject in its yesterday's issue, remarks as follows

We recently asserted that the time was not yet ripe for indulging in suoh an unnecessary demonstration as the reception it is proposed to hold in honour of Mustapha Pasha Kamel. We are convinced that no native of Egypt has as yet deserved to be received here with the waving of banners and the gathering of crowds of people to greet him as he passes by. The Pasha has done nothing vary remarkable, and during this year he has not gone beyond what he did on other occasions except to pay a visit to London where he made his voice penetrate to the ears of the British public. For this we all thank him. If, however, the forthcoming reception is merely to consist of a banquet at a Cairo hotel, and there are no other demonstrations, we have nothing to criticise. The banquet in his honour will be a function on a similar footing to those recently given to the translator of the Iliad and the author of Antar. The expressions, therefore, made use of in the invitation issued by Mohamad Farid Bey such as "a magnificent reception and a huge banquet" are exaggerations.

div.head: SULTAN NOT SERIOUSLY ILL.
div.p: The Berlin correspondent of the "Petit Parisien" says :—
I learn that Professor Bergmann has made the following statement concerning the Sultan's illness :—

"The first time I saw the Sultan and had an opportunity of conversing with him I received the impresseion—-although I did not have an opportunity to examine him —that I was not in the presence of a man suffering from a grave malady.

"Subsequently I was able to make a careful medical examination, which proved to me that my first impression was correct. The Saltan had only an internal complaint, which was healing, and slight gravel symptoms. He was not suffering any considerable pain.
' I may add that I did not observe symptoms of any other disease in the Sultan, who is far from looking very ill."

The eminent Parisian surgeon, Dr. Doyen, giving his opinion on the Sultan's illness, said that if the Sultan is really suffering from the disease attributed to him, the removal of the kidneys, which in a man of the Saltan's age might be fatal, is the only possible remedy.

div.head:
ALEXANDRIA - TRIESTE.
NEW EXPRESS STEAMERS.
div.p: Now that Trieste has at last been brought into direct communioation with Germany, this popular route between Egypt and Europe will become more patronised than it is at present. In anticipation of the great increase in traffic between Alexandria and the great Adriatic port, the Austrian Lloyd Company have decided to increase their fleet as well as to accelerate the service. The plans of the new steamer which the Company intend adding to their fleet have been studied with the utmost care, so that nothing shall be wanting ; that it may suit the traffic for which it is intended, and allow of the transport of the regular number of passengers with the greatest degree of comfort. Thus the proposed ship will be of about 16,000 tons' displacement. The steamer will be lighted throughout with electricity and will be fitted with a new hearing system. There will be accommodation for about 380 first and second class passengers. A special feature of the boat will he its magnificent promenade deck, 210 feet long and 15 feet wide throughout.

div.head: GABBARY TRAFFIC.
div.p: In reference to the extension reforms, which the Egyptian State Railway are making at Gabbary, the following statement showing the tonnage of traffic handled at Gabbary during the last five years will be of interest :—

It will be observed that the export traffic has practically remained stationary, whilst there has been a considerable increase in imports. The import traffic in 1905 was about 65 per cent. heavier than the export traffic The effect of this is to necessitate large numbers of waggons being hauled to Gabbary empty, thus increasing the non-remunerative kilometrage, and reducing the revenue per goods- train kilometre.

Two new cotton platforms were brought into use for the cotton season, but more accommodation is required before the cotton can be handled in a thoroughly efficient manner. Considerable difficulty was experienced in dealing with the cotton seed consigned to the quays for direct export owing to the conversion of part of quay "E" which had previously been used for this class of traffic, into an import quay. This new arrangement reduced the siding accommodation for dealing with exports by nearly one half, and a large number of waggons had to he held back until they could be received on the quays. On three occasions booking of cotton seed to the quays had to be suspended for three days. The lack of inward reception sidings, in which to sort out waggons for their respective berths, has been seriously felt ; it is hoped, however, that the new inwards marshalling yard now in course of construction will greatly improve matters in future. The gravitation marshalling yard for outwards traffic has been of great service in the despatch of trains.

div.head: THE "SUCRERIES."
div.p: The syndicate of bondholders of the Société Générale des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte has sent the following circular to the interested parties:—

Le Conseil d'administration du Syndicat des porteurs d'obligations à revenu variable de la Société Générale des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte, constitué à Paris le 31 janvier 1906, pour sauvegarder, dans les limites assignées par le Concordat et conformément aux statuts, les intérêts des Obligataires, a été informé que la Société des Sucreries invitait les porteurs à procéder à l'échange et à l'estampillage de leurs titres.
D'après l'annonce qu'a fait paraître la Sooiété dans les premiers jours de septembre, l'estampillage des titres, ainsi qu'il est prévu au Concordat, devait prendre fin le 20 septembre 1906.

Le Conseil d'administration du Syndicat, considérant que la brièveté du délai imparti, ne permettait pas aux Obligataires, surtout à cette époque de l'année de procéder à cet estampillage en temps utile, a présenté à ce sujet une observation à la Société des Sucreries.

La Société a déclaré qu'elle avait voulu simplifier pour les porteurs les formalités de l'échange, de l'estampillage et du paiement du coupon, en les réunissant en une seule opération ; mais des retards indépendants de sa volonté nelui ont pas permis d'arriver plus tôt à la confection des nouveaux titres. La Société a donné satisfaction au désir exprimé par le Syndicat au nom des Obligataires, en prorogeant le délai accordé pour l'estampillage jusqu'à la date du 31 décembre 1906, ainsi qu'il résulte de la note parue dans les journaux le 20 courant.

Le Conseil du Syndicat s'est préoccupé également de l'admission à la cote des nouvelles obligations. La Société des Sucreries lui a fait connaître que les démarches nécessaires auprès de la Chambre Syndicale des Agents de Change, étaient déjà effectuées, et qu'elle espérait que la cote des nouvelles obligations serait obtenue dans le courant du mois d'octobre.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. City of Cambridge arrived yesterday at noon from Liverpool and Malta with passengers and general cargo.
The Ellerman S.S. City of Venice sailed from Liverpool yesterday for Malta and Alexandria with passengers and general cargo.

div.head:
THE BRINDISI MAIL.
ACCIDENT CAUSES DELAY.
div.p: The Brindisi mail will not arrive at PortSaid to-day owing to the non-arrival of the P. & O. S.S. Isis. It is stated that that steamer went ashore off the North coast of Crete, but we have been unable to obtain any confirmation of this news.
The Isis is expected to arrive at Port Said to morrow evening, and the mails will consequently not be delivered until Friday.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan arrived at Alexandria from the Piræus on his yacht the Cuchona yesterday afternoon. His Highness, who has been accompanied throughout his voyage by Mr. Kephala, has had a delightful cruise in the Mediterranean for the last three months, during which he has visited Naples, Venice, the Dalmatian coast, and the Islands of the Æegean sea.
It is reported that Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel's palace at Ghizeh has been sold to an English company for L.E. 400,000.
Slatin Pasha, Inspector General of the Sudan, returns to Cairo on the 8th inst.

According to the latest information received from Captain Hall, R.E., the Goods Manager of the Egyptian Government Railway, that official had an interview in London with the late Major L'Estrange Johnstone on Thursday week at the offices of Lieutenant Colonel Western, R.E., Inspecting Engineer in England. The Major then complained of feeling somewhat seedy, but he appeared to be quite able to transact business.

Sir William Garstin, Adviser to the Minister of Public Works, leaves Marseilles by the P. and O. Marmara on the 12th on his return to Egypt. A number of English engineers who are to be attached to that Ministry are passengers by the same boat.
Mr. P. W. Machell is expected to arrive from England on the 10th inst.
The Dowager Countess of Seafield and Lady Nina Ogilvie-Grant are arriving at Port Said shortly by the P. and O. steamer Moldavia, which sails from London for the East on October 12.
The Hon. Arthur Davey, late of the "Sucreries," has just arrived at the Hotel du Louvre, Paris, from London.
Mr. Charles Baehler, the Managing Director of the Egyptian Hotels Limited, will arrive at Alexandria from Europe on Monday next by the North German Lloyd S.S. Hohenzollern.
Miralai Torner Bey, director of posts and telegraphs in the Sudan, is now in Cairo to confer with the financial secretary of the Sudan Government regarding the budget for 1907.
Mr. Perry, of the Ministry of Public Works, returned to Cairo yesterday morning.
Lieut.-Col. W. M. Dackett, A.P.D., has returned from leave.
Lieut. Walter F. Stirling, D.S.O., Royal Dublin Fusiliers, has been seconded for service with the Egyptian Army.
Lieut. I. H. Dimick, inspector of army schools, will leave Cairo to night for Khartoum.
Farid Bey Babagoglu returns on the 12th inst.

div.head: FAREWELL TO THE K.R.Rs.
div.p: The farewell smoking concert given last Saturday evening at the Soldiers' Club, Cairo, prior to the departure of the 1st King's Royal Rifles for Khartoum, and a number of details, leaving by the transport Sicilia for England, was the most successful ever held in the club. A very large audience of members and their friends were present, including Colonel Cuthbert, commanding the Army of Occupation, Major Hoskins, D.S.O., and other officers. The programme was an excellent one, the instrumental part being performed by the string band of the 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers, under the baton of Mr. Miles, and was much appreciated, their exeoution being a treat to musical critics. The vocalists were, without exception, well received. Those who found most favour were Captain Tucker, who, in excellent voice, gave "Father Molloy" and "My Dear Old Dutch"; Pte. Jones, Lancashire Fusiliers, who sang excellently "My Dear Little Cingalee" ; Sergt. Hall, 6th Dragoons, who was very amusing in his song "Mrs. Done-again ;" and the Harlene Brothers, who brought down the house with their parody and patter, especially, in those verses in which military, political,or local matters were touched upon. Pte. Fairclough's get-up was exceptionally well designed and his dancing most excellent. The songs were well accompanied by Sergt. Godfrey, Sapper Newton, and Pte. James.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE,
div.p: (Communication Officielle)
La Délégation Municpale s'est réunie le 2 Octobre 1906 à 5 h. p.m. sous la présidence de S.E. le Dr. Schiess Pacha.
Présents MM. J. Barbaza, Mansour Bey Youssef, Yehia Pacha, Amb. A. Ralli, G. Zervadachi, membres ; I. Sedky Bey, secrétaire.
La Délégation prend connaissance d'une demande des habitants de Kom el-Chogafa El-Barrani tendant au dallage et à la construction de canalisations dans diverses rues de ce quartier.

Après examen d'une note da service de la voirie, au sujet de cette demande, la Délégation charge le service d'élaborer le devis des travaux réclamés, sauf à soumettre la question à l'étude du Comité des Travaux Publics.
La Délégation décide renvoyer à l'examen du Conseil du Tanzim la pétition des habitants da Camp de César, à l'Ibrahimieh, tendant à la cession des rues de cette localité.
Elle renvoie au Comité spécial chargé de la révision des allocations, une demande de la Société Maltaise de bienfaisance pour une augmentation de l'allocation qui lui est allouée.
Communication est donnée da projet de règlement en vue d'arrêter le recensement de la taxe de 2 % chaque quatre années.
Ce projet sera vélocigraphié et distribué aux membres pour son examen à une prochaine séance.
La séance est levée à 7 h. p.m.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Toute l'attention s'est concentrée aujourd'hui sur le Comptoir et la Cassa di Sconto.

Le Comptoir s'avance jusqa'à 6 29/32 pour revenir en clôture à 6 25/32 ; la nouvelle atteint 6 9/16. Cette hausse serait dûe à l'imminence de la prochaine assemblée et à l'accapare-ment des titres qui en est la conséquence.
De son côté la Cassa touche 228 l'ancienne et 221 1/4 la nouvelle, en hausse respective de 1 fr. 25.
Par contre la National Bank recule de 1/16 à 26 11/16, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 1 fr. à 337 et les Lots Turcs de 2 fr. à 147.
La priviligiée Tramways réactionne de 190 à 189, tandis que la dividende remonte de 330 à 332.
La Daïra gagne 1/8 à 36 5/8.
Tout le reste du marché reste sans changement.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Tries et Boutigny. NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres a haussé hier de 1/8 à 4 1/2 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a gagné 1/8 à 86 5,8. L'Unifiée est restée invariée à 104 1/4, de même que la National Bank à 26 7/8 l'Agricole à 9 3/4, la Daïra à 16 3/4 et la Delta Light à 11 5/8.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien est remontée à 782 et la Banque d'Athènes à 146.
L'emprunt russe 1906 a passé, à Paris, de 82. 40 à 83. 70 ; à Londres, il s'est relevé de 79 7/8 à 80 1/4.
Ici, nous avons eu, ce matin encore, une séance animée avec des cours soutenus sur presque toute la ligne, à l'exception de la National Bank et de la Delta Land.

La National Bank a débuté aux abords de 26 15/16 pour descendre à 26 3,4. L'Agricole s'est raffermie à 9 11/16-3/4. La Cassa di Sconto a encore progressé à 227-228 l'action ancienne et à 220 la nouvelle.
L'action Crédit Foncier a été mieux tenue à 780 781 ; l'obligation à lots ancienne est revenue à 337 338. La Béhéra a gagné 1/4 à 36 1/2 Le Wardan Estate a fléchi à 6 15/16.

La Nile Land a été poussée, de 15 3/16-1/4, aux environs de 16 pour finir à 15 11/16-3/4. A noter qu'en vertu de l'article 6 des Statuts, les 45,000 actions déférées à M. Bacos pourront être détachées de la souche et négociées par leur propriétaire le 13 Octobre courant, c'est-à-dire exactement deux ans après la constitution de la Société.
L'Immobilière s'est consolidée à 487-388. L'Enterprise and Development a avancé de 1 /4 à 12 3/4. Les Improvements ont atteint 5 3/1 pour clôturer à 5 5/8-11/16.
L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a été échangée à 4 1/4 5/16 ; la part de fondateur, très recherchée, a progressé à 74-75.
Les Automobiles ont atteint 5 7/8 pour revenir à 5 13/16-7/8 ; la part de fondateur a été cotée 10 3/8.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont été délaissés à 17 7/16. Les Egyptien se sont raffermis à 6 5/16. En bonne tenue, les Upper Egypt ont été négociés à 5 1/16-1/8. Les National ont clôturé à 4, ache-teurs, et la part de fondateur à 59.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont réactionné a 3 7/6 1/2. La part de fondateur Estates a faibli à 11 9/16. Les New Egyptian ont clôtaré à 30 sh. Les Abdy ont molli à 1 1/4 et les Sucreries à 25. Les Salt and Soda ont fait 21 sh. 9.

Hier, après Bourse, à Alexandrie, la National Bank a été traitée à 27. Eu Bourse, les privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie ont passé de 186 à 187,50; les Dividendes ont gagné 2 francs à 340. En forte demande, la Port-Said Salt Association a été négociée entre 16 sh. 9 et 16 sh. 10 1/2. Les Building Lands ont été ramenés à 4 7/8.
M. Mack, membre du Board de Londres de l'Egyptian Land and General Trust Ltd (Hooker) se trouve depuis mercredi passé au Caire.

Ou sait que, suivant les déclarations faites à l'assemblée ordinaire tenue à Londres le 14 Septembre dernier, M. Mack a été délégué en Egypte pour prendre en mains la direction des affaires de la Société et procéder à la vente des terrains dont la cession serait jugée opportune :

Interviewé au sujet de la rumeur relative à un prochain appel de fonds, M. Mack aurait déclaré qu'il n'avait rien appris de positif à ce sujet depuis son départ de Londres. M. Mack est parti hier pour Alexandrie.
Nous détachons d'une lettre de Paris, en date du 25 Septembre, les lignes suivantes :

"Les fonds russes, qui avaient baissé l'autre jour sur des bruits de complot contre le Tsar, ont été mieux tenus hier. Néammoins, la situation difficile du Trésor russe continue à préoccuper beaucoup les esprits. Ainsi ou parle de la reprise des pourparlers pour transformer la Banque d'Etat russe en Société par actions. Les négociations seraient, parait-il, conduites sans passer par le ministère des finances. Le gouvernement voudrait sanctionner ce projet par une loi provisoire que la nouvelle Douma ne pourrait pas modifier. Il faut ajouter que ces rameurs sont plus ou moins démenties. On affirme tout de même que l'emprunt intérieur de 50 millions de roubles n'ayant pu être placé chez les banquiers a été prélevé sur les fonds des caisses d'épargne.

"Il y a, d'autre part, amélioration sur le Tarc, qui a été si fortement atteint samedi passé : on cote 94.50 au lieu de 94.40. Cependant, sur l'état véritable de la santé da Sul-tan, on n'est ni plus ni moins renseigné ; mais, selon toute probabilité, la spéculation va avoir là un bon sujet à mouvements. Les porteurs de fonds ottomans ne sauraient être trop vigilants : ils agiraient sagement en faisant passer les nouvelles à venir au crible d'une sérieuse vérification.

Ainsi que nous l'avons déjà fait remarquer, les parts de jouissance des Tramways Electriques da Caire ont donné lieu, la semaine dernière, à d'intéressantes fluctuations à la Bourse de Bruxelles. Ce titre, qui était coté Frs. 992,50 le 18 septembre, a haussé à 1005 le lendemain, à 1022,50 le 20 septembre et à 1065 le 21. Il est revenu à 1050 le 24 septembre pour clôturer à 1051,50 le 25.

div.p: Deux employés bons comptables disposant de quelques heures par jour demandent tenir livres de commerce. Bonnes références. Professeur français diplômé, cherche leçons à domicile.
Un professeur d'arabe et de comptabilité d'un des plus grands établissements d'instruction de la ville désire donner des leçons particulières.
Jeune homme de 25 ans connaissant la comptabilité, l'arabe, le français, l'italien, le turc et un peu l'anglais cherche emploi.
N. B.— Pour tous renseignements s'adresser au Siège Social de la Société, Rue Mosquée Attarine No. 21.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat a l'honneur d'informer le Public que la Station de "Moalla" située entre Chagab et Mataana (Ligne Louxor-Assouan) sera à partir du 11 Octobre 1906, ouverte pour le service des voyageurs et transport des bagages et animaux en Grande Vitesse aux prix et conditions da Tarif des Voyageurs en vigueur.
Toutefois des billets directs et l'enregistrement direct des bagages et animaux de ou pur El-Moalla ne se férait que de et pour les gares de la voie étroite (Louxor-Chellal).

Pour les voyages et transports des gares de la voie normale (au-delà de Louxor) à destination d'El-Moalla et réciproquement, les billets et récépissés seront émis pour Louxor seulement, d'où l'on devra prendre de nouveaux billets et effecteur un nouvel enregistrement par les soins et aux frais des voyageurs on des expéditeurs.
Le Caire, le 1er Octobre 1906. 28602-2-1
AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de Fer et des Télégraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Public que le Bureau Télégraphique de Kaha sera ouvert, à partir du 3 Octobre courant, pour l'échange des correspondances eu langues européennes et arabe.
Le Caire, le 2 Octobre. 28612 2 1

div.head: Municipalité d'Alexandrie. AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les fournitures de bureau nécessaires à l'Administration pour la durée de trois années 1907.8.09.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 100.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Service de la Comptabilité Générale où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 b. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité, avant le 6 Novembre 1905.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation, le même jour à 5 h. p m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la men-tion "Soumission pour "Fournitures de bureau."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément an Service de la Comptabilité Générale, avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 6 Novembre prochain à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur (Signé) Dr. Schiess.
Alexandrie, le 2 Octobre 1906. 28611-3-1

div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal

div.head: Neglected Colds cause Consumption.
THE WHITE SCOURGE
div.p: MRS. ADDIE HARDING. MRS. MARY MEYER. MRS. FRANCES WILSON.
PROBABLY every case of consumption begins with a cold.
Consumption is generally classed as a hereditary disease, but consumption is not hereditary.
A constitutional weakness is inherited which renders one liable to consumption.
Even people who have strong lungs may acquire consumption from a cold.
Mrs. Addie Harding, 121 W, Brighton Ave., Syracuse, N. Y., writes:
"I have been a user of Peruna for the last twelve years and can truthfully say that there is no better medicine on earth.
"A SURE PREVENTATIVE."
"With me it is a sure preventative for colds and many other ills. In my home can always be found a bottle of Peruna. Two or three times a year I am troubled with my throat.
"I always had to have the services of my physician two or three times in each case.
"Although a user of Peruna, I never thought of taking it for my throat until about two years ago.
"I tried Peruna to check it, and to my great delight I was not troubled with the smothered and choked feeling and never have since.
"I can check it every time with Peruna.
"I certainly would not be without Peruna one minute."
Mrs. Mary Meyer, Thomson avenue, near Shell Road, Winfield, L. L, N. Y., writes:
"I have been annoyed with a cough for years.
"Often it was so bad that I could not sleep half the night. Many people thought I had consumption.
CONSUMPTION WAS FEARED.
"A woman recommended Peruna to me two years ago. I began to take Peruna and now I am perfectly free from a cough,
"I am glad to say that Peruna cured me entirely, I take Peruna occasionally when I do not feel well and I also give it to my children.
"Peruna is the best medicine for coughs and colds. I have told many people how much Peruna has helped me."
A neglected cold is a well-worn path to consumption.
Many a person catches cold and pays no attention to it.
He scarcely recovers from the first cold when he takes the second.
Still he gives it no heed, and possibly takes another cold, and so on.
He doses himself with bromides, quinine and various expectorants.
His case is catarrh, at this stage, and his case should be treated as catarrh.
A common cold is acute catarrh.
Finally, if the cold is allowed to continue, it becomes chronic catarrh.
Mrs, Frances Wilson, 82 Nelson street, Clinton, Mass., writes:
"Had you seen me at the time of my illness and now, you would not wonder that 1 take delight in sounding the praises of Peruna.
"My ailment was a severe cold which attacked the bronchial tubes and lungs.
"I followed your special directions and after using six bottles of Peruna I was on my feet again.
"I think Peruna a wonderful medicine."
All colds, coughs, bronchitis, laryngtis and tonsilitis should be treated as catarrh, as they are in reality catarrh.
The success of Peruna in relieving these cases entirely depends upon the fact that Peruna is a catarrh remedy.
It relieves catarrh wherever located in the system. Whether in the throat, bronchial tubes or lungs.
CONSUMPTION PREVENTED.
It has saved a multitude of peo-ple from consumption by eradicating catarrh before it reaches the lungs.
The tendency of catarrh of the throat or head is to spread downward to the lungs.
If taken in time, Peruna will prevent these cases.

We have in our files many testimonials from people who thought they were victims of consumption, but have been permanently relieved by the faithful use of Peruna. thus showing that catarrh was really the cause of their ailments.

For special directions everyone should read " The Ills of Life." a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists at five shillings per bottle or six bottles for twenty-five shillings.

div.head: BLUNT'S ANTI-NATIONALISM.
div.p: The following is the text of Mr. Blunt's letter to the "Times" : —

It is an unlooked-for pleasure to me—a true reminiscence of my golden political youth—to find myself, after a silence of some 20 years, once more attacked in the "Times" about Egypt, and by my old adversary there, your Alexandria correspondent of the early eighties. In those days we had so many bouts together in your columns that I feel the pulse of battle rising in me at the sound of his challenge, and I take it up with joy. Even your own severe strictures on my supposed lack of patriotism are not altogether unwelcome as a testimony to the influence which my long devotion to Egypt enables me to exercise there at the present crisis. You exaggerate, indeed, my anti-English attitude, but I am not ashamed of avowing that on the Nile it is Egyptian, not English Imperial interests, that are my first concern ; I have been domiciled there now for over a quarter of a century, and Egypt has become to me a second country, which I love almost as dearly as my own.

As to the events of 1882, your correspondent does me a service by reminding Liberal readers of the "Times" of the part I half involuntarily played in the constitutional struggle at Cairo of that year, and of the partial, if not full, success I achieved in pleading the national Egyptian cause in England. It is a matter of pride with me to remember that I was able to persuade Mr. Gladstone, if only for a few months, to sympathize with liberty in Egypt as he had sympathized with it in Greece, Italy, and Bulgaria; that I succeeded in defeating for a while the treacherous plans of our diplomacy, and that my encouragement stiffened Egyptian patriotism to the point of armed resistance in a wholly righteous case. Above all, I am glad to remember that my advocacy of Egyptian nationalism prevented the supreme iniquity intended of annexing Egypt after Tel El Kebir. These are not achievements of which any lover of liberty needs to be ashamed. Nor am I in the least afraid that when the full narrative of my relations with Downing-street from 1880 to 1886 comes to be published, as it will some day, the discredit of my disagreement with Mr. Glastonc—and it was never a very wide one-- will be mine. Sir Edward Grey, if rightly understand his words in the House of Commons on July 5 last, admitted that in regard to those events the Liberal party had "learned much," and, I suppose, repented much.

So much for the prose of the affair. Your correspondent also reproaches me for my verse. It is quite true that, as he reminds your readers, I published in 1883 a poem called "The Wind and the Whirlwind," and that in it I indulged in certain vaticinations about Egypt and the British Empire the whole of which have not yet been fulfilled. I predicted woe to England through her suppression of liberty in Egypt, and I predicted a resuscitation of the nations of the East which, if she did not mend her ways of unsympathetic government, would end in her Imperial ruin. Surely it is strange that in a letter and a leading article, both written to show the danger our Eastern Imperial interests are threatened with, that with the spectacle of of Japan victorious in arms before us, of China's awakening, of Bengal in a ferment of political agitation, of Persia demanding a Parliament, and of Egypt exasperated to a condition of "perilous unrest," my dreams of 1883 foreseeing just such things should be counted to my discredit. Your correspondent has quoted a few stanzas from my poem. Permit me, however irregular it may be for a poet to recite his own verses in the "Times," to quote a few more of them. " The Wind and the Whirlwind" has long been out of print, and is therefore inaccessible to the mass of your readers. They will, besides, better than I could do it in any other way, justify my political position, which you have so unsparingly assailed. The verses I will choose apostrophizing England are these : -
div.l: "O insolence of strength ! O boast of wisdom !
O poverty in all things truly wise !
Thinkest thou, England, God can be outwitted
Forever thus by him who sells and buys ?
"Thou sellest the sad nations to their ruin.
What hast thou bought ? The child within the womb,
The son of him thou slayest to the hunting,
Shall answer thee 'an Empire for thy tomb.'
"Thou hast joined house to house for thy perdition.
Thou hast done evil in the name of right.
Thou hast made bitter sweet and the sweet bitter,
And called light darkness and the darkness light.
"Thou hast deserved men's hatred. They shall hate thee.
Thou hast deserved men's fear. Their fear shall kill.
Thou hast thy foot upon the weak. The weakest
With his bruised head shall strike thee on the heel.
"The Empire thou did'st build shall be divided.
Thou shalt be weighed in thine own balances
Of usury to peoples and to princes,
And be found wanting by the world and these.
"Thou had'st no pity in thy day of triumph.
These shall not pity thee. The world shall move
On its high course and leave thee to thy silence,
Scorned by the creatures that thou could'st not love.
"Truth yet shall triumph in a world of justice.
This is of faith. I swear it. East and west
The law of man's progression shall accomplish
Even this last great marvel with the rest.
"Thou would'st not further it. Thou can'st not hinder.
If thou shalt learn in time thou yet shalt live,
But God shall ease thy hand of its dominion,
And give to these the rights thou would'st not give.
"The nations of the East have left their childhood.
Thou art grown old. Their manhood is to come ;
And they shall carry on earth's high tradition.
Through the long ages when thy lips are dumb,
"Till all shall be wrought out. . ."
div.p: These verses will not convince out correspondent, nor will they convert the Stock Exchange. Yet there are not a few English conversant with the modern facts of Asia who will see in them events which yet may come. At least they represent my consistent creed, the reason of my political action in the East.

div.head: WHERE BRITAIN IS LOSING.
div.p: Japan is rapidly purchasing foreign machinery, the amount last year exceeding £1,230,000. Previous to 1896 it purchased no electric motors, and in that year only £1,400 worth. The importation in 1905 aggregated £245,540, of which two thirds came from the United States. Only £20,000 of locomotive engines were purchased by Japan in 1892, but for the past three years the importations have always exceeded £200,000. American and German locomotives are now gaining supremacy where the British make formerly led.

div.head: WHERE SUICIDE PREVAILS.
div.p: There is an article in the "Civitta Cattolica" on "Suicide in the Nineteenth Century" in which the writer deduces from statistics the fact that self-destruction is far more frequent in Protestant than in Roman Catholic countries. From 1871 to 1900 no fewer than 300,000 cases were registered in Germany alone. France, Saxony, and Denmark contribute the greatest number of suicides in proportion to their population ; in Norway, Sweden, England and Germany the percentage is less, while in Belgium, Italy, Spain, and Austria it is lower still.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in the spirit of fair play to all, to permit--within certain necessary limits--free discussion.

div.head: MR. BLUNT AND HIS WRITINGS.
div.p: To the Editor OF the ' Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—With your indulgence I should like to tell the world and Mr. Blunt that I have read his little book. Before proceeding I would warn the incautious reader that Mr. Blunt must not be taken as synonymous with "the world." Mr. Blunt himself might also note.

In "Atrocities of Justice under British Rule in Egypt" one constantly must refer to the title to make certain of what one is reading. The impression constantly conveyed is that Mr. Blunt is telling the story of his life-of his rise to greatness, of his wide-reaching influence in the world's, and more especially in Egypt's, affairs. He would have us believe that the powers that be in Egypt tremble when Mr. Blunt opens his mouth, in fact, that Mr. Blunt's comings and goings are the sole subject of conversation in the official world of the Nile Delta. As a piece of fiction I suppose Mr. Blunt's book has a certain value.

Mr. Blunt speaks of British rule in Egypt for the last twenty-four years and allows his audience to assume that of that whole period there is not more than a stray bank-holiday unregistered in that portion of his physical apparatus where most men's brains are. And yet (without counting the troublous period of 1882) Mr. Blunt can only point to six instances in which at a trial of law between native and English, the former has been (in Mr. Blunt's estimation) manifestly ill treated. Even examining the dossiers in these cases with his spectacles, and assuming that his eyes have not been blinded by the Egyptian sun, the record is one upon which any Power occupying a foreign territory, and surrounded on all sides by enemies, might well congratulate itself. Had there been more than the odd half-dozen cases cited by Mr. Blunt, we should have had detailed accounts of the same in "Atrocities of Justice, etc."

It is scarcely necessary to inquire what are the arguments employed by Mr. Blunt. The pamphleteer "like the poor" is always with us, and his arguments are the old traditional ones. In all of Mr. Blunt's so-called impeachments his condemnation rests on the turn of a word, the distortion of a phrase, or the paraphrasing to suit his own ends of sentences used in their official decisions by English authorities. His pet arguments begin or end with "I have reason to believe," "it can be inferred from what I have said," or "in my opinion."

Mr, Blunt delights in three things— namely "italics," "disclosed secrets," and "special dossiers." Mr. Blunt's "italics" are to his war of words what scalps were to the Red Indians. He is prepared to wreck and kill for the sake of a lock that suits his fancy ; and to deface seemly paragraphs ad libitum. His "open secrets" are themselves a study in ambiguity ; and the "special reports" prepared and handed to Mr. Blunt on each and every event that ever happened in Egypt would make numerous volumes of a history of our own times. Do not let the callow reader ask of this modern Daniel "from whence come these strange reports." He might as well ask of Rameses "who broke the nose of the Sphinx," or of Isabella "who's got the button." Mr. Blunt knows, but refuses to tell.

In conclusion it may be remarked that despite the colossal dimensions of Mr. Blunt, he is never truly great until he threatens, first the British Empire, and then Lord Cromer. As for the British regime both in India and in Egypt, its members stand (or in the late hot weather sit) aghast. Lord Cromer still enjoys the shooting in Scotland. Mr. Blunt would have us believe that his Lordship learned to shoot by picking off Egyptian fellahs. As for the rest of the world, now that the "Arbiter Judiciarum" has thundered portentous rumours are afloat: the Congo Free State insists on enquiring into the internal administration of Lesser and Greater Britain, while it is related on exceptional authority that Lapland will move towards the partition of "the Empire on which the sun never sets."

div.head: OFFICIALS AND CIVILIANS.
div.p: To THE Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette.

Sir, - I am sure the commercial section of the British Community of this city will feel deeply grateful to your correspondent, the Anglo-Egyptian official, whose letter from Medinet el Fayoum appeared in your issue of Friday last. This gentleman, who has evidently had the benefit of a public school and 'Varsity education, labours under the impression that the members of the British commercial colony here have all been educated at board-schools. But we ought to be deeply grateful to him for his condescension in pointing out that such a curriculum does not entirely exclude us from some refinement for, as he is at pains to declare, "refinement is no more the result of a 'Varsity and public school training than is the lack of it the result of being taught at a board school. Refinement is a gift of nature, and where it does not exist originally, no kind of subsequent training will produce more than a very spurious form of that virtue, which will quickly disappear in any crisis."

According to this official, therefore, some of us business men may have the gift of refinement in spite of our board-school education. This concession deserves remembering, for it is a sample of how broad-minded the English official in Egypt can be in some of his ideas. The patronising tone of this gentleman's attitude may grate upon our feelings, but he evidently believes what he says and we ought to be heartily grateful to him for showing us the point of view with which the officials regard the command herd of commercial men of their own race in Cairo.—I am, Sir, Truly Yours.

div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. div.head: Notice.
SUDAN GOVERNMENT.
DISPOSAL OF BUILDING SITES AT PORT SUDAN.
div.p: The Sudan Government will shortly dispose by Tender of about 400 Building Sites at Port Sudan.
The sites will be Leasehold held at Annual Rents on Building Lease for Eighty Years from 1st January, 1907. Rents will Repayable only from date of acceptance of Tender.
The Lease will be Perpetually Renewable at Revised Rents fixed in default of Agreement by Arbitration at the end of each term of years.
In fixing the revised rents the value of Buildings erected by Lessees will Not be regarded as a ground for Increase of Rent

Example : If a plot is leased for a term of 80 years from 1st January 1907 then on the expiration of that term the Lessee will have a right (subject to observance of his convenant etc) to obtain a fresh lease for a further period of 80 years at a revised tent, and so on in perpetuity. The revised rent will be calculated on the value the site would bear if it were vacant building lands.
Offers are invited of Premiums for the Purchase of the above mentioned leasehold sites.
All offers must be made by Tender, on the forms issued by the Sudan Government, and must be received at Khartoum not later than 1st January 1907.

Particulars of the sites offered, Plan of the Town, Conditions of Tender and Sale, Form of Tender, specimen Form of Lease, etc., will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to inspection at the following places during the usual business hours :
Khartoum : *Office of Director of Agriculture and Lands (T) and Office of Governor of Khartoum Province.
Cairo: *Office of Sudan Agent (T).
Port Sudan : Office of Inspector (Government Office) (T).
Suakin : Office of Governor of Red Sea Province.
El Damer : Office of Governor of Berber Province.
Atbara : Office of Director of Railways.
Alexandria : Office of Mr. Macpherson Grant.
Port Said : Office of Dixon Bey, War Office Representative.
London : *Office of Col. Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster, and the Sudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez : Office of Capt. Falconer, War Office Representative.

For the convenience of intending purchasers the Conditions of Tender and Sale have been translated into Arabic and French and copies of the translations into either language will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. per copy at the Offices in the above list which are distinguished by a capital T.
Further information will be obtainable after the publication of the above-mentioned documents on application in writing to The Director of Agriculture and Lands, Khartoum.
* Copies of the Documents will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. or 1 Shilling per copy at the Offices marked with an asterisk.

div.head: GOUVERNEMENT DU SOUDAN.
Concessions de Terrains a Batir a Port-Soudan
AVIS
div.p: Le Gouvernement du Soudan va prochainement disposer, par voie d'adjudication d'environ 400 parcelles de terrains à bâtir à Port- Soudan.

Les dites parcelles seront données à bail emphytéotique, pour une durée de 80 années à partir du 1er Janvier 1907, moyennant loyer annuel, à charge pour le locataire de bâtir. Le loyer ne sera payable qu'à partir de la date de l'acceptation de l'offre.
Les baux seront renouvelables à perpétuité moyennant un loyer variable fixé à la fin de chaque terme, soit d'accord, soit par arbitrage.
En fixant le nouveau loyer, la valeur des bâtiments élevés par le locataire ne sera pas considérée comme un motif d'augmentation de loyer.

EXEMPLE : Si une parcelle de terrain est louée pour une durée de 80 années à partir du 1er Janvier 1907. Dans ce cas, à l'expiration de ce délai, le locataire aura un droit (à condition d'observer les conditions du bail) d'obtenir un nouveau bail pour une nouvelle période de 80 années, moyennant un loyer modifié, et ainsi à perpétuité.
Le loyer modifié sera calculé sur la valeur du terrain, s'il était libre de construction.

Des offres sont demandées pour les baux emphytéotiques dont s'agit ; ces offres devront mentionner la prime que le soumissionaire est disposé à payer au comptant en sus des loyers annuels établis pour chacun des lots. La dite prime devra être payée en un seul versement à la signature du contrat de bail.
Toutes offres doivent être faites par soumission, sur les formules dressées par le Gouvernement du Soudan, et doivent être reçues à Khartoum avant le 1er Janvier 1907.

Le détail des terrains offerts, le plan de la ville, les conditions de l'adjudication et de la concession, la formule de soumission, spécification du bail, seront à la disposition du Public à partir du 1er Octobre 1906, aux lieux ci-après indiqués, durant les heures de bureau.
Khartoum*—Bureau du Directeur de l'Agriculture et des Terrains (T) et bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Khartoum.
Le Caire* Bureau de l'agent du Gouvernement du Soudan (T).
Port-Soudan*—Bureau dé l'Inspecteur (Bureau du Gouvernement (T).
Souakim—Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province et de la Mer Rouge.
Wadi-Halfa—-Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Halfa.
El-Damer—Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Berber.
Atbara—Bureau du Directeur du Chemin de Fer.
Alexandrie—Bureau de Mr. Macpherson Grant.
Port-Saïd—Bureau de F. Dixon bey, Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.
Londres—Bureau du Colonel Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster et le Soudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez—Bureau du Capitaine Falconer, Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.

Pour la commodité des acheteurs éventuels, les conditions d'adjudication et de concession, ont été traduites en arabe et en français et des copies de ces traductions, dans les deux langues, peuvent être obtenues, à partir du 1er Octobre 1906, moyennant payement de P.T. 5 par copie, aux bureaux mentionnés dans la liste ci-dessus, qui sont suivis d'une lettre majuscule T.

Des informations supplémentaires peuvent être obtenues après publications des documents pi-dessus mentionnés, moyennant demande écrite adressée au Directeur de l'Agriculture et des Terrains, à Khartoum.
* Aux bureaux marqués d'uue astérisque, copies des documents pourront être obtenues à partir du 12 Ootobie 1906, moyennant payement do P.T. 5 ou un shelling par copie. 28497-12*-1
